extension.dc:title: Plinian Core Simple Extension
extension.name: Plinian Core
extension.dc:subject: plic:Plinian Core; dwc:Taxon
extension.dc:description: Plinian Core is a set of concepts that defines the necessary basic attributes to integrate and recover the information about species of organisms required by users specialized in biodiversity as well as users of other areas. This extension is supposed to be used in addition to the taxon core and the simple images, vernacular names and references extension.

property.name: TaxonRecordID
property.dc:description: Unique identifier of the record within the database.
property.examples: "8fa58e08-08de-4ac1-b69c-1235340b7001", "32567", "http://species.gbif.org/abies_alba_1753", "urn:lsid:gbif.org:usages:32567"

property.name: GlobalUniqueIdentifier
property.dc:description: An Uniform Resource Name (URN) used as an unique identifier of the taxon record.

property.name: Abstract
property.dc:description: General description of the taxon. This concept could point out any information about the taxon. Its main goal is summarize the most relevant or attractive characteristics of this taxon to the general public.
property.examples: A mottled bluish-grey rorqual which is the largest living animal and reaches lengths of up to 27 m [Balaenoptera musculus].

property.name: Language
property.dc:description: Language used to write the species information, ISO 639-2 according to GBIF Metadata Profile, Reference Guide http://links.gbif.org/gbif_metadata_profile_guide_en_v1.
property.examples: "spa", "eng",...

property.name: AudiencesUnstructured
property.dc:description: Users to which the information is addressed. The defined audiences are: Biodiversity researchers, teachers and students, decision makers, professionals from another areas and general public.This list audience codes has to be separated by means of comma or /.
property.examples: "Teachers and students", "Decision makers"

property.name: SynonymsUnstructured
property.dc:description: A list of scientific names used for this taxon as a text block
property.examples: Geranium acaule L., Geranium bangii Hieron., Geranium caespitosum Walp., Geranium malpasense R. Knuth

property.name: DetailUnstructured
property.dc:description: Unstructured information regarding the names of the species or taxon, whether these are scientific or not.
property.examples: "Pronunciation", "etymology"

property.name: BriefDescription
property.dc:description: Brief description, presented in a simple technical language, to distinguish the species from other close or similar ones.
property.examples: Cap 8–20(30)cm, brown often with a whitish bloom at first gradually lost on expanding leaving a white line at the margin, smooth and dry initially becoming greasy, in wet weather slightly viscid and polished. Stem 30–230 x 30–70(110)mm, robust, pallid with white net. Flesh white, unchanging, flushed dirty straw-colour or vinaceous in cap.

property.name: FullDescriptionUnstructured
property.dc:description: Complete and detailed account of the taxonomic and systematic characters, usually comprising several sections, and not limited to the diagnostic features.

property.name: Keys
property.dc:description: Tool for the identification of organisms, comprising a series of steps, each of which represents a question about one or more characters of the organism. Each step offers multiple alternatives, choosing one of them will lead us to the next step until reaching, finally, the name of the organism. Most of the keys only offer two alternatives, the so called dichotomous keys. A taxon can include an identification key for the subordinate taxa.
property.examples: The register of a genre will include the keys of the species shown in this genre, and the register of a species will include the keys of infra-specific ranks (in the case of plants: subspecies, variety, forms...)

property.name: LifeFormUnstructured
property.dc:description: General appearance. Characteristic mode of growth or occurrence associated to its environment, particularly for plants. Comprising its size, shape, texture and orientation. In block text format
property.examples: "Tree", "Shrubs", "Herbs",...

property.name: LifeCycleUnstructured
property.dc:description: Life history of a living organism: The course of developmental changes in an organism from fertilized zygote to maturity or stages through which an organism passes. In block text format.
property.examples: "The fungus fruit body is the spore-producing stage of the life cycle. The spores produced by fruit bodies are usually the result of sexual reproduction. The fruit body is supported by and develops from an extensive network of thread-like filaments called hyphae. Hyphae are often collectively termed the mycelium; the food-absorbing part of the fungus. When conditions are favorable, and the mycelium is at the proper stage of development, fruit bodies are produced by the fungus. The spores produced by a fruit body are released initiate the life cycle anew."

property.name: ReproductionUnstructured
property.dc:description: All data related to the production of offspring as a block of text.
property.examples: It has both sexual and asexual reproduction (fragmentation), although sexual reproduction is little known and its expansion is mainly due to the dispersion of fragments in coastal marine areas of low depth (up to 30 meters deep) where it finds the ecological conditions suitable for their settlement and proliferation

property.name: Event
property.dc:description: An action in the natural history of the species that occurs at some location during some time. A controlled vocabulary is recommended.
property.examples: "flowering", "migration", "courtship", "hatching "

property.name: StartTimeInterval
property.dc:description: The date-time or interval at which an event starts. Recommended best practice is to use an encoding scheme, such as ISO 8601:2004(E). A controlled vocabulary is recommended.
property.examples: "1963-03-08T14:07-0600" is 8 Mar 1963 2:07pm in the time zone six hours earlier than UTC, "2009-02-20T08:40Z" is 20 Feb 2009 8:40am UTC, "1809-02-12" is 12 Feb 1809, "1906-06" is Jun 1906, "1971" is just that year, "2007-03-01T13:00:00Z/2008-05-11T15:30:00Z" is the interval between 1 Mar 2007 1pm UTC and 11 May 2008 3:30pm UTC, "2007-11-13/15" is the interval between 13 Nov 2007 and 15 Nov 2007.

property.name: EndTimeInterval
property.dc:description: The date-time or interval at which an event ends. Recommended best practice is to use an encoding scheme, such as ISO 8601:2004(E).A controlled vocabulary is recommended.
property.examples: "1963-03-08T14:07-0600" is 8 Mar 1963 2:07pm in the time zone six hours earlier than UTC, "2009-02-20T08:40Z" is 20 Feb 2009 8:40am UTC, "1809-02-12" is 12 Feb 1809, "1906-06" is Jun 1906, "1971" is just that year, "2007-03-01T13:00:00Z/2008-05-11T15:30:00Z" is the interval between 1 Mar 2007 1pm UTC and 11 May 2008 3:30pm UTC, "2007-11-13/15" is the interval between 13 Nov 2007 and 15 Nov 2007.

property.name: AnnualCycleUnstructured
property.dc:description: Set of changes or events that recurrently take place at the same time of year and are influenced by seasonal and inter-annual climate variations. For example: reproduction, flowering, fruiting, emergence of insects, etc. Also called phenology, mainly in plants. In the case of migration, refers only to the timing of it; other data about this are gathered in MigratoryData. In block text format.
property.examples: The butterfly hibernates over winter, The pairs only mate once after overwintering, eggs are laid in early spring, in batches of up to 400 at a time

property.name: FeedingType
property.dc:description: Primary diet source. A controlled vocabulary is recommended.
property.examples: "Autotrophs", "Heterotrophs-Herbivores", "Heterotrophs-Carnivores", "Heterotrophs-Omnivores", "Heterotrophs-Saprophagous", "Heterotrophs-Detitivores",...

property.name: TrophicStrategy
property.dc:description: Tactic used to obtain energy or nutrients. A controlled vocabulary is recommended.
property.examples: "Chemosynthetic organisms", "Photosynthetic organisms", "Parasites", "Decomposers", "Suspension feeders", "Substrate feeders", "Grazers", "Fluid-feeders", "Predators",...

property.name: TrophicStrategyRemarks
property.dc:description: Unstructure notes about feeding strategies.
property.examples: an occasional scavenger

property.name: FeedingUnstructured
property.dc:description: Information related to supply food for the development and sustenance of the individual and-or its offspring as text block.
property.examples: It hunts rabbits and other mammals (including rodents and insectivores), birds (especially the red-legged partridge[citation needed]), reptiles and amphibians, most actively during twilight and at night

property.name: DispersalType
property.dc:description: Means or vector of dispersal. A controlled vocabulary is recommend.
property.examples: "Zoochory", "Anemochory", "Hydrochory", "Barochory", "Autochory"...

property.name: StructureDispersed
property.dc:description: Mechanism or structure which seeds are dispersed. A controlled vocabulary is recommend.
property.examples: "Seed", "Fruit", "Vegetative structure", "Spores", "Gametes", "Eggs", "Offspring and Individuals"...

property.name: DispersalUnstructured
property.dc:description: The permanent spreading of individuals away from each other not including return. Dispersal determines the range over which genetic mixing occurs, and thus, the degree of homogeneity and inbreeding in a population. In block text format.
property.examples: It is dispersed by small fragments that are dragged or carried in the anchors or nets of the boats.

property.name: BehaviorUnstructured
property.dc:description: Responses, reactions or movements made by an organism in a particular situation. In block text format.
property.examples: It is able to leap up to 50 times its size. They use a tether of silk that they produce from their bodies to do so. They are able to use the hydraulic movement of their limbs in spite of not having muscles in their body to do so. They do have to stop now and then to be able to readjust their blood pressure. They are very curious by nature too. This is why they will leap when a human places their hand out. However, they may jump backwards too so that they can get enough distance from that object. They stay focused for long periods of time on what they approach too

property.name: InteractionSpeciesType
property.dc:description: String with the type of interaction. Each element is seperated by comma and each list of elements by ;. A controlled vocabulary is recommended.
property.examples: "predation"," parasitism;predation", "parasitism"

property.name: InteractionUnstructured
property.dc:description: Mutual or reciprocal actions or influences. For example, predation, parasitism, mutualism, etc. Relations with products grown and stored by man (plagues) are also included. In block text format.
property.examples: It is a predator of small invertebrates. Leeches appear to be a major source of adult mortality. It is predated by birds, mammals, fish, and other amphibians, however many of them are deterred by the its toxic skin secretions.

property.name: MolecularDataUnstructured
property.dc:description: Information on the chemical structures and biological processes at the molecular level: DNA and proteins sequences, protein structures, expression profiles of genes protein domains, families of genes, mutations, polymorphisms, involvement in disease, ... Undeveloped. Placeholder for connecting with standards developed by specialists. For example, Standards for Data Exchange and Management from Scalalife (http://www.scalalife.eu/content/data.html). As free text.
property.examples: "The main toxins in Digitalis spp. are the two chemically similar cardiac glycosides: digitoxin and digoxin"

property.name: MigratoryUnstructured
property.dc:description: The regular, usually seasonal, movement of all or part of an animal population to and from a given area, which can occur in variable periods of time and even involve more than one generation. In block text format.
property.examples: Birds from northern and eastern Europe are migratory and move to southern Europe or Africa. Birds from central Europe often stay in the breeding areas, especially the males [Mebs & Schmidt 2006].

property.name: EcologicalSignificanceUnstructured
property.dc:description: Ecological importance of the taxon. (Placeholder). In block text format.
property.examples: They are vital within their ecosystem for the production of oxygen and organic material and they support numerous animal species that utilise them as a site for breeding, feeding and shelter.

property.name: EnvironmentalEnvelopeUnstructured
property.dc:description: Set of environmental conditions within which it is believed that the species can persist; that is where its environmental requirements can be satisfied. In block text format.
property.examples: The temperature range for the Mediterranean strain is 7°C - 32.5°C, while the maximum salinity is 38 ppt (NIMPIS, 2002).

property.name: WhatImpact
property.dc:description: An indication of the actual impact as a free text string.
property.examples: "Destroys riparian vegetation", "Destroys irrigation systems", "Displaces Arvicola sapidus",...

property.name: Vector
property.dc:description: By which means a species occupies a new territory.
property.examples: "fishing boats", "dirty boots", "cars (Aedes albopictus)"

property.name: Route
property.dc:description: This is equivalent and probably replaceable by gisin:route.
property.examples: Eggs and larvae, or infested cladodes, were sent from Nevis to Montserrat and Antigua in 1962 and to Grand Cayman in 1970 (Bennett et al. 1985). By 1963 the cactus moth had invaded the Lesser Antilles to Puerto Rico (Garcia-Tuduri et al. 1971)

property.name: impactTarget
property.dc:description: This is equivalent and probably replaceable by gisin:target
property.examples: "Environment", "HumanHealth", "Economy", "Unknown"

property.name: impactMechanism
property.dc:description: Mechanism of introduction or impact to a new location. This is equivalent and probably replaceable by gisin:impactMechanism.
property.examples: They clog pipes by forming colonies inside of the pipes

property.name: InvasivenessUnstructured
property.dc:description: Information about invasive exotic species that could threaten to ecosystem, habitats and species. As a text block
property.examples: In forests it competes with seedling trees and can slow their establishment and growth. Pampas grass creates a fire hazard with excessive build-up of dry leaves, leaf bases, and flowering stalks.

property.name: HabitatUnstructured
property.dc:description: General description of the sites where the species is found (ecosystem, forest, environment or micro-habitat). (Placeholder). In block text format
property.examples: This plant grows at altitudes of between 1,500 and 3,400 meters, under high levels of ultraviolet radiation, Iow atmospheric pressure and extreme temperature and humidity

property.name: DistributionUnstructured
property.dc:description: Comment about the distribution of the species based on information from the collection sites of the studied specimens. A a text block.
property.examples: Primarily in Turkey and far E Greece, secondarily in the Crimea, Caucasus coast, Azerbaijan, Iran, Iraq, Syria, Lebanon, Crete and Cyprus; primarily near coasts, in areas with a strongly Mediterranean climate.

property.name: EndemicUnstructured
property.dc:description: Organism that lives exclusively in a particular territory and not found anywhere else. As a text block.
property.examples: It is a South Iberian endemic (Spain),

property.name: TerritoryUnstructured
property.dc:description: Information associated mostly to vertebrates, referring to the territorial extension of the individual or group in terms of its activities (feeding, mating, etc.). As a text block.
property.examples: The species will forage over vast distances (up to 700 km in one day has been recorded).

property.name: PopulationBiologyUnstructured
property.dc:description: Study of the variations in time and space as well as size and density of populations, and the factors that cause such variations. As a text block.
property.examples: In Europe, the population has grown in the Alps (with the emergence of new breeding pairs due to a reintroduction project, with 19 pairs in 2010), and in the Pyrenees, particularly in its central part (Aragon, Spain), from its population of 39 pairs in 1994 to 72 pairs in 2010. In Spain, two reintroduction projects are under way in Andalusia and the Cantabrian Mountains. The total population in EU countries was estimated at 175 pairs in 2010 (J. A. Gil Gallus in litt. 2011).

property.name: ThreatStatusUnstructured
property.dc:description: Information about the status of the taxon.As a text block.
property.examples: poison and electrical cables considered the biggest threats

property.name: DirectThreatUnstructured
property.dc:description: A free text describing sources of stress and proximate pressures that are impacting or may impact the threat status of the taxon. Threats can be past (historical), ongoing, and/or likely to occur in the future.

property.name: LegislationUnstructured
property.dc:description: A national proposed law or group of laws. A regional proposed law or group of laws. In block text format.
property.examples: Spain: Catálogo Español de Especies Exóticas Invasoras Norma: Real Decreto 630/2013, de 2 de agosto. Fecha: (BOE nº 185): 03.08.2013. Orden de 20 de marzo de 1996.

property.name: UsesUnstructured
property.dc:description: Ways in which species are utilized by people. Including Folklore. As a text block.
property.examples: The Common Osier has the ability to absorb some heavy metals like cadmium, and is often planted to reclaim industrial sites

property.name: ManagementAndConservationUnstructured
property.dc:description: Management: actions directed at conserving or restoring species / Conservation: interventions undertaken designed to preserve species. As a text block.
property.examples: The eradication work entailed physical and chemical methods, and avoided the use of heavy machinery in order to reduce damage to the environment. It consisted of hand-pulling seedlings (over 590 ha)
